text: Happiness. So many people are chasing it
and so few of those people manage to
crack the code of what it truly means to
be happy. It can feel like happiness is
just out of reach. Like no matter what
you achieve or acquire in life, it's
never enough. If you've ever felt this
way, know that you're not alone. In
fact, according to IPSOS, a global
research company, just under a third of
people worldwide would not describe
themselves as happy. For many, happiness
is elusive. But there are a few things
we can do to help it along. In today's
video, we're going to explore why
chasing happiness might actually be the
very thing keeping you from it. This is
what we call the happiness trap.
Afterwards, we'll share a 7-day plan
aiming to help you reset and kickstart
yourself onto the road to happiness. So,
what does it really mean to be happy? A
big question. Happiness is a word we
hear all of the time. Social media is
flooded with posts about finding it.
Self-help books promise to unlock its
secrets. And yet, so many of us feel
further from it than ever. Why? Well,
because we've been sold a lie about what
happiness really is. Let's break it
down. According to Martin Celigman, one
of the founding fathers of positive
psychology, happiness isn't just about
fleeting pleasure or euphoria, true
happiness, or well-being is a
combination of positive emotion,
engaging in activities and interests,
relationships, and finding meaning and
accomplishment in life's trials and
tribulations. It's a balanced and
sustainable state, not a constant high.
So happiness is not the rush we feel
when we get likes on social media or the
fleeting joy when we purchase something
new. It's also definitely not the idea
that you should feel amazing all of the
time. When we confuse happiness with a
state of constant pleasure, we fall into
the happiness trap. The happiness trap
is the belief that happiness is a
destination. that if we just achieve
this one thing, a promotion, a
relationship, an amount of money, then
we'll finally be happy. But what happens
when you get there? You enjoy it for a
moment, and then you're right back where
you started, chasing the next goal. This
phenomenon of constantly needing to
achieve the next goal has a name, the
hydonic treadmill. It's the idea that no
matter what happens in your life, you
quickly return to a baseline level of
happiness. Face a setback, you adapt.
Win the lottery, you celebrate, but you
adapt. Get splashed by a car in the rain
on the way to work. It is what it is. I
mean, you're going to have wet clothes
for the rest of the day, but guess what?
You'll adapt. The treadmill of life
keeps moving and you keep running. But
the catch is you're really not going
anywhere. This concept can be both
disheartening and freeing. It can also
explain why people who seem to have it
all, like money, fame, and success, they
can often still feel unfulfilled. There
are a number of myths about being happy
that fuels the happiness trap. But
before we dive in, let's talk about an
important part of this journey.

Instead of pursuing happiness, we need
to cultivate contentment. Contentment is
about appreciating what you have,
finding joy in the present moment, and
building systems that support long-term
well-being. Let's break this down into
three key ideas. One, focus on the
journey, not the outcome. Two,
prioritize your well-being over
pleasure. Three, embrace the full range
of human emotions, good or bad, sad or
mad. But how do we put this stuff into
practice? Well, let's go through a 7-day
plan packed with ways to finally break
free of the happiness trap and live a
more content life. The 7-day
breakthrough plan. This plan will help
you start building a more fulfilling
life. Each day, you'll focus on simple,
actionable tasks, and by the time you
finished, you'll have a great framework
to begin living a more content life. Day
one, gratitude and reflection. Start
your day by writing down three things
that you're grateful for. Gratitude
rewires your brain to focus more on the
positive. In the evening, reflect on one
moment that brought you joy out of the
day, no matter how small. Day two,
connect with others. Call or meet up
with someone you care about, or why not
rekindle an old friendship? Research
shows that strong relationships are one
of the biggest predictors of happiness.
As psychologist Martin Seligman said,
other people are the best antidote to
the downs of life and the single most
reliable up. Day three, mindfulness and
presence. Spend 5 minutes meditating or
practicing mindfulness. Focus on your
breath or the sensations in your body.
This is proven to help you stay present
and reduce anxiety and tension. Day
four, acts of kindness. Do something
kind for someone else. Could be as
simple as complimenting a co-orker or
buying a cup of coffee for a stranger.
Studies show that acts of kindness boost
your happiness just as much as the
person you were kind to. Day five,
physical activity. Exercise for at least
20 minutes. Whether it's walk, yoga, or
workout, physical activity releases
endorphins and improves your mood. Day
six, find meaning. Spend time finding
something that gives your life meaning.
This could be a hobby or an activity
that makes you feel great. Examples of
this could be a personal project,
volunteering, or learning a new skill.
But remember, happiness comes from the
act of doing something and the purpose
you feel doing it, not just pleasure.
Day seven, digital detox. Take a break
from social media and screens for a full
day. Use the time you gain from this to
connect with nature, read a book, or
just simply relax. This will probably
feel harder than you realize, but it's a
really good way to help you reset and
focus on what truly matters. This 7-day
plan can seem like a lot to fit into
anyone's busy life. So, if it's too
much, try focusing on each day's theme
for a few days at a time. By the end of
the reset, you'll feel calmer, more
connected, and be able to see the
positive more than you did before.
Breaking free from the happiness trap
isn't about giving up on happiness. It's
about redefining it. By focusing on
contentment, building systems of
well-being, and embracing life's ups and
downs, you can create a life that's not
only happier, but also richer and more
meaningful. Remember, happiness isn't a
destination. It's a journey. And every
step you take, no matter how small,
brings you closer to the life you want
